results.title: Paddington turns detective
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
Paddington receives a torch from Mr Gruber as a gift and receives an answer to his morse code signals from Mr. Brown’s greenhouse! He assumes the identity of Feathers Locke, Detective and proceeds to investigate, even fingerprinting Mr. Brown’s prize marrow! Adapted from Michael Bond’s book ‘More about Paddington’. Narrated by Michael Hordern. Music by Herbert Chappel.

results.title: To die for
results.creator_credit: Gus Van Sant, Laura Ziskin, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Gus Van Sant’s vicious black comedy stars Nicole Kidman as Suzanne Stone, a vapid and celebrity obsessed sociopath whose dream to become a famous TV personality turns into a nightmare for the people around her. In her determined quest for stardom Suzanne bullies her way into a job as a weather woman for a local cable station, much to her husband’s (Matt Dillon) growing displeasure, and shrewdly uses it as a way to instigate her own pet projects. Through one such project, a documentary about teenagers, she meets and befriends three of her subjects, Jimmy (Joaquin Phoenix), Lydia (Alison Folland) and Russell (Casey Affleck), three awkward teens with very low self esteem. Jimmy and Lydia take a particular liking to the glamorous and confident Suzanne who seizes on their crush as a way to manipulate them into helping her achieve her own murderous goals. Buck Henry’s (‘The Graduate’) caustic screenplay is serviced well by Gus Van Sant’s direction, which chronicles Suzanne’s ruthless climb to the top of the American dream through a series of first hand accounts from the various characters. Joaquin Phoenix and Alison Folland are impressive as the painfully shy teens, while Kidman’s performance is spot on as the cold and calculating Suzanne. Cast also includes Illeana Douglas and Dan Hedaya. (Awards: Golden Globe Award for Best Actress-Nicole Kidman) See also ‘Drugstore Cowboy’, ‘My own private Idaho’, ‘Good Will Hunting’.

results.title: To Catch a thief
results.brief_description: The French Riviera serves as the picturesque backdrop for this classic, suspenseful Hitchcock caper with Cary Grant as John Robie, a reformed cat burglar once known as “The Cat”, suspected in a new wave of jewel thefts from luxury hotels. Meeting pampered heiress Frances (Grace Kelly at her most ravishing), he sees the chance to bait the mysterious thief with her mothers’ (Jessie Royce Landis) fabulous jewels and clear himself of suspicion. His plan backfires, but Frances, who believes him guilty, proves her love by helping him escape and in a spine-tingling climax, the real criminal is exposed. Script including the much-imitated fireworks scene by John Michael Hayes. The cinematography by Robert Burks won the Oscar for Best Cinematography, 1954. Co-starring John Williams, Charles Vanel, Brigitte Auber, Jean Martinelli and Georgette Anys. Based on the novel by David Dodge.

results.title: Mr Gruber's mystery tour
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
Adapted from chapter 4 from the book “Paddington marches on” by Michael Bond. Mr Gruber takes Paddington on a visit to the Wax Museum where Paddington is astonished and amazed at what he sees. Paddington has never visited the Wax Musem before. Narrated by Michael Hordern.

results.title: The Woodlanders
results.creator_credit: Phil Agland, Barney Reisz, Pathe Productions and Channel Four
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Thomas Hardy, “The Woodlanders” is a passionate story of love. Giles Winterborne (Rufus Sewell) and Grace Melbury (Emily Woof) have had an agreement to marry since childhood. However, Grace’s return from boarding school and subsequent elevation in society cause their engagement to be called off. Silently adored by his friend, Marty, Giles continues to pine for Grace, whilst she in turn falls in love with the handsome new doctor, Fitzpiers. But as they follow their separate courses, Grace and Giles find that their lives become inextricably entwined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Phil Agland, Barney Reisz, Pathe Productions and Channel Four

results.title: The Wonderful world of dogs
results.creator_credit: Mark Lewis, Channel 4, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Film Commission and Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: 540,000 dogs inhabit the city of Sydney and every one with a story to tell. This whimsical, humorous film tells some of them, and in particular, the story of Fugly, the most impounded dog in Australia, and his impact on the suburb of Mosman. Dog lovers and dog haters alike express their point of view as we watch Fugly roaming the streets. “Some dogs just want to be dogs. Some people want dogs to be people. But dogs will be dogs … and people will be people. We all live together.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Lewis, Channel 4, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Film Commission and Radio Pictures

results.title: Tuktu and the trials of strength
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
Strong and hardy Inuit hunters demonstrate and test their strength in boxing, tug-of-war, and other strenuous activities. We see and hear the drum dance, a demonstration of Inuit poetry and rhythm.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Tuktu and the clever hands
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
A general look at some of the things made by the Inuit and a commentary on the clever use that they make of the few materials that are available in their harsh environment. We come to the conclusion that they are highly skilled, overcoming problems that to us would seem almost insurmountable.

results.title: You can't shift the blame
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Jack Zalkalns, Barry Pierce, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1980 film focuses on safety practices for operating mobile cranes and warns against the main types of mishaps and accidents that can occur. The film dramatises the importance of maintenance; setting up on solid ground; load charts and labels; and the role of the ‘dogman’ who directs the operation of the crane from near the load. The voiceover’s tone is casual and familiar, with use of colloquial terms such as ‘galah’. The footage of worksites is introduced and interspersed with an interview with a department official, reflecting on the dangerous and fatal accidents that have occurred.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Tuktu and the big kayak
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde, David Bairstow and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Stories of Tuktu”.
Tuktu impatiently watches his father and the kayak man build a kayak. He longs to cut wood and use the bow drill, but is told to watch and learn. In the end the boat is finished, and Tuktu goes for a ride in it with his father.
